My sister and I didn't speak for nearly 3 years.

Next weekend, she's coming to visit.

As I instinctively reacted YES to her message about a stay at my house... it dawned on me.

I'm not afraid anymore.

For a very long time, I was too triggered to hang out w/ family. 

I couldn't bare the pain of her not validating my childhood experience. I was in a constant state of frustration tryin to get her to see things my way.

I couldn't appreciate her for who she is, or where she's uniquely at on her journey.

Over the years reconnecting, we've found common ground. And while we still don't see eye-to-eye on everything...

there's mutual respect.

The arguments and name calling turned into civil disagreements.
The civil disagreements turned into opportunities for bonding.

new levels of safety, for both her and I. 

I now realize THIS IS us breaking generational cycles, rather than falling victim to the patterns of separation that plagued so many before. (I guess that's the stubbornness of the Irish for ya...)

So, when I heard her childlike energy through the phone as she shared how excited she is to book a trip to come see me... I had a moment of reflection on how far I've come that instead of my usual knee-jerk reaction to shut her out, anticipating unnecessary drama and a "I'd just rather not deal with this" attitude...

I instead just smiled and of course told her,

YES!

Actually, I'm excited too! :) 

and damn that's a whole lotta growth.

Not to mention - it was a good excuse for me to finally clean out my guest room which has basically been used as storage unit since I moved back in November.

It's been FB Marketplace ads all weekend over here.

I was removing the top mattress that I once also had on this bed, when I noticed cat urine!

Ugh.

I decided to list anyways (for free), w/ a disclaimer about the cat pee... but if you want to come pick it up, it is yours.

A woman showed up in a beat up car w/ her husband & kids, incredibly grateful for a free, cat-pissed mattress.

Today I ran a mile in 6:40.

Funny thing is, I'm heavier than I've ever been in my life weighing in now at almost 160. 

Let's just say - the bulk season has been real.

But rather than just a simple post to show of my progress and paradisiacal Florida views -Â Â let me enlighten you all on the pain it took to get here.

When drugs no longer work.
When men no longer work.
When LI no longer works.

I work.

It's more about the actual physical NEED for exercise because of my mental health, I simply cannot function without it.

I put in mad discipline the past couple years destroying as much as I possibly could that was distracting me from my pain. That meant giving up drinking, dating, even smoking weed which believe me I had DEEP attachments to since the age of 14.

It even meant giving up my virality on social media and squeezing the hose on my own company. Another distraction - one that made money, but I knew I had to force myself to crash and burn to find out what I was truly made of.

Thing is,

all addicts end up at the gym.

But since I moved back to Orlando, I decided I needed someone to push me again.

My latest trainer had me running miles around the lake at the end of the workouts and I was surprised to see, (despite little distance training these days) that within the first 2 weeks I was coming in at 7:08.

Today he challenged me to get to 6:30...

Close enough ğŸ˜†

The most gratifying thing about all of this is that I remember my best mile time. It was 6:34 back when I ran cross country in High School.

I was 17 years old.

That's 15 years ago.

Last year at age 31, I did a metabolic test (Vo2Max) that tested my biological age as only 19. (per my heart rate variability and running to failure on treadmill)

#winning! 

The point is - people can look at a girl like me and think I got lucky. PAH! - 

I GET IT'S EASIER TO THINK THAT.

Sorry, it's not at all the case. 

My success in life has been directly correlated to my ability to ENDURE. PAIN!

You think I don't wanna veg out on the couch and eat a tub of ice cream? Smoke pot? Call dudes and distract myself with validation & fun?

Of course I do. The pleasure seeking ran deep.

But eventually you get sick and tired of your own BS.

Eventually you get sick and tired of playing small. Of limiting your own potential. Of dumbing yourself down to make others around you more comfortable about their own lazy ass life.

F*ck em.

I wanna be great, and if fitting in isn't gonna get me there, I'm not gonna fit in. I wanna be 42 testing age 29 on the Vo2Max. (or younger!)

This isn't about vanity.

It's about longevity.

I owe that to myself, looks are a bonus.

How healthy is your heart? 
How's your digestion? 
How is your skin? 
Your energy?

These will all be markers to you as to how legit your wellness routine actually is.

My life has been a series of slowly giving up all the things I used to survive all my life. My hardest challenge ever was weed. As a daily pot smoker since age 14, I'm proud to say I'm over 3.5 years clean.

Booze was easy, I just didn't like how it made me feel anymore. I much prefer Kratom tea as a social stimulating substance.

I was a serial monogamous always depending on a man to "hold my bigness". Convinced I couldn't do it alone - when I'd only been programmed that way. I have been single for almost 3 years now. The biggest blessing.

All these years chipping away have allowed me to slowly build the capacity for independence and true freedom. When God knocked on my door again a few months ago and said, "Time to lock in!" I knew I had to give up caffeine & Kratom.

It sucked.

Kratom was weekly, but coffee daily. Lots of sleepless nights and a complete hormonal reset, until I reached month 2 and the fruits of my labor began to show.

I started going to Yoga 3-5x a week.
I started weight training 4-5x a week.

I started making skits again. I embarked on a long overdue goal of learning FL studio so I can produce my own music. I have always been into songwriting, it's how I got into editing way back when... but this time is different.

Being able to produce tracks in FL is like learning Premiere Pro on steroids.

The sobriety I gained coupled with the right-brain activation through piano lessons, FL music creation, and skit production?

Massive somatic release.

I cried like I have never cried before.

I remembered things about my childhood previously only accessible through Dimethyltryptamine (DMT/Ayahuasca).

I pieced a lot together and I mourned all by my lonesome.

The combination of Yoga & Weight training helped a lot. Together my trainer and I discovered a beautiful recipe for somatic release, perhaps one other survivors of sexual abuse can learn to tap into. I realize I was never really pushing myself until failure because when I did, I suddenly began exploding into tears.

An awkward moment for my trainer, at first. Until we bonded deeper over it and developed clear communications about what was happening and releasing in my body during these sessions.

Yoga helped, music helped, sobriety helped - but I truly credit my biggest somatic releases this summer to LIFTING HEAVY WEIGHTS!

My fitness sessions became the greatest asset to my recovery. Not to mention I'm feeling strong & sexy AF!

Anyways, that's enough grief for now. Ready to swim, scuba dive, and get funky down in Key West for a few weeks... so grateful to finally be here!

Inside the cave you fear is the treasure you seek.

Do painful shit.
It's worth it.

Last summer I got denied buying a 2nd home and ended up moving to the keys.

It was one of the most challenging times of my life.

Psychologically uprooted.

No place to live.

Suddenly alone on an island, with no idea why God led me down here.

To think that same villa I rented last year which I couldn't wait to get out of, a villa in which I had the worst insomnia of my life, detoxed kratom, blew through 3 journals and processed so much while feeling lost and alone...

I'd end up willingly booking again, and coming back to this summer.

Whole different energy.

This island saves me. I think when I'm down here, "why don't I just stay?" When we grow up in a certain environment where we know no different, it's a very challenging feat to discover the other side.

For some people it's love they never get. 
For some people it's money they never get.

For me it was safety.

I grew up in extremely psychotic circumstances so that my body never knew what safety felt like. I was likely this way from the womb, taking on the same distorted nervous system and sickness of my mother.

I have always lived my life on high alert. My drug of choice, aside from actual mind-altering substances... has actually always been to CÍŸOÍŸNÍŸTÍŸRÍŸOÍŸLÍŸ.ÍŸ

I think things through 500 times, if not more.

I consider the feelings, thoughts, and energy of everyone around me.

I learned to manage it all, take it all on as my responsibility.
I was forced to metabolize everyone else's pain,

but nobody ever held mine.

This island holds it.
